Award.AwardTitle: MRI Consortium: Development of Environmental Control for Resonant X-ray Scattering on Organic Samples
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nanoscale interactions and structures within organic materials are of critical importance for our understanding of their macroscopic properties and functions. These organic materials range from engineered (e.g. Kevlar, polymer batteries) to biological (e.g. cellular proteins), but what is common among them is that final solid properties are seeded during liquid processing or that many of their properties and functions only occur in specific operational environments. Resonant soft X-ray scattering (RSoXS) is uniquely capable of probing the nanostructure of these materials using intrinsic chemical bonds within the molecules, but currently RSoXS can only be performed on samples suspended in a vacuum. In this project, RSoXS will be combined with environmental control suitable to create the conditions in which these organic systems operate. The developed instrument will be first of its kind and provide an exquisite view into the molecular interactions and structures that govern formation and operation of organic matter during such formation and operation, and therefore, enable leaps in understanding and control of materials for technology, energy, and life. The availability of such facility will continue to place the USA at the international forefront of X-ray science for many years to come.

Resonant soft X-ray scattering (RSoXS) utilizes intrinsic chemical sensitivity of absorption fine structure of molecular transitions from core electronic orbitals. The technique, therefore, is uniquely sensitive to molecular bonds and their orientation in organic materials where no or low crystallinity and/or density contrast exists and, furthermore, does not require laborious and potentially disruptive labeling. Thus it is particularly useful in investigating interactions and structures of small molecules, polymers and proteins that drive materials properties and biological functions. Currently, however, samples are investigated in vacuum, limiting the study of these materials. This project funds the development, construction and installation of sample environmental control for RSoXS at beamline 11.0.1.2 of the Advanced Light Source (ALS) at Berkeley National Laboratory. Such an instrument will enable measurements of nano-to-mesoscale structure and interaction of organic molecules under full environmental control (gasses, liquids, temperatures, electric fields, and charges). The project will combine the superior sensitivity and selectivity of RSoXS to organic molecules and their orientations with the ability to measure their structure and interactions in their in-situ or in-operando environments. Such an ability to probe organic matter in their native environment is critical to obtaining information that is relevant to the very applications in which they form, exist and function.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

A new instrument has been constructed to enable investigation of organic nanostructures in their native environments and under operating conditions of their applications. This involves nanostructures in fluids, under coordinated mixing and reaction, at controlled temperatures, and in the process of electrochemistry. These new environments and stimuli leverage the base technique of resonant soft X-ray scattering, a nanoprobe sensitive to molecular bonds and even their orientation within a nanostructure. The instrument has been installed at the soft X-ray beamline of the Advanced Light Source (ALS) at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (LBNL) where 1000s of current annual researchers conduct their research for free. This instrument will be maintained and made available to all researchers with instrument maintenance, support, and training provided by the ALS staff scientists.

New technologies were invented for this instrument, in particular, a novel aluminum oxide membrane technology that protects the sample environment from vacuum required for X-rays, while allowing X-rays to penetrate the sample. Additionally, optimized sample environments for X-ray measurements have been developed to fully take advantage of this new capability. In particular, the physical dimensions of the protective encapsulating cell were optimized and flow rates and times of water and oil-based liquids were determined. A fast (5 min) physical interface for inserting liquid samples into the high vacuum chamber of the instrument was additionally developed, which will enable these sample environment capabilities to be expanded to the more than 20 other X-ray instruments at the ALS. The new instrument additionally enables both X-ray experiments and electron microscopy experiments on the same sample, enabling a deeper view into these critical nanostructures. Electron microscopies can be carried out at the National Center for Electron Microscopy on the LBNL campus for free with a successful project proposal.

Several scientific demonstrations of the new measurement capabilities were also conducted. These involved elucidation of microfibril structure in cell walls, protein shape analysis in solution, and micelle nanostructure and dynamics for drug delivery and hydrocarbon-capturing. These results have been disseminated to the scientific community through more than eight presentations at major conferences and three publications in peer-reviewed scientific journals. A central postdoctoral researcher additionally recruited multiple potential new users of the instrument in scientific fields that currently do not use the technique. This will expand the scientific impact and user base of the new instrument for years to come. Five PhD candidates and one postdoctoral researcher were involved in the project, furthering their careers as the next generation of US scientists and engineers.
